data.abstract: This chapter describes viruses as small organisms that retain infectivity after passage through filters small enough to hold back bacteria. Bacteria are measured in terms of the micrometre (μm), which is 10-6 of a metre. For viruses, the nanometre (nm) is used as the unit, which is a thousand times smaller. The chapter points out that viruses are totally dependent on living cells, either eukaryotic or prokaryotic, for their replication and existence, and possess and carry enzymes of their own. Viruses cannot reproduce and amplify and translate into proteins the information in their genomes without the assistance of the cellular architecture and protein translation machinery, namely ribosomes. The chapter discusses viruses that possess only one species of nucleic acid, either DNA or RNA, and have a component for attaching or ‘docking’ to cells so that they can commandeer the cells as virus production factories.
title: General properties of viruses

data.abstract: This chapter begins its explanation with photos of a child with measles, an elderly patient with severe herpes zoster, and another child with a malignant tumour of B-cells that can affect the jaw which is known as Burkitt’s lymphoma (BL). Each of these people is under attack by a virus. The chapter notes that the manifestations differ greatly, not only in appearance, but also in the way in which the viruses concerned cause these unpleasant effects. The chapter talks about measles, which is an acute infection of children. Most patients recover quite quickly and develop immunity against a second attack, while the zoster rash is caused by a reactivation of a lifelong persistent infection with a herpes virus. Lymphoma is caused by another herpes virus that has transformed immune B-cells. The chapter focuses on complex interactions between viruses and hosts that result in disease–in other words, with the pathogenesis of viral infection.
title: How viruses cause disease
Spontaneous segregation of nontransforming viruses from cloned sarcoma viruses

data.abstract: This chapter focuses on adenoviruses, which were first isolated from human adenoids. They cause widespread disease that ranges from colds to pneumonia and diarrhoea to bladder infections. Adenoviruses infect the eye, gut, and respiratory tree. The chapter looks at the study of adenovirus replication, which led to important discoveries of messenger RNA splicing. Members of the family Adenoviridae are icosahedral, non-enveloped linear dsDNA viruses of which some are 80 nm in diameter. The chapter highlights the five recognized genera of the adenoviruses: Mastadenovirus, isolated from mammals and humans; Aviadenovirus, isolated from birds; Atadenovirus, isolated from birds, mammals, and reptiles; Ichtadenovirus, isolated from fish; and Siadenovirus, isolated from reptiles and birds.
title: Adenovirus: respiratory, eye, and gastroenteritis viruses
original-title: Adenovirus: respiratory, eye, and gastroenteritis viruses
